title: Attention Is All You Need
authors: Ashish Vaswani, Noam Shazeer, Niki Parmar, Jakob Uszkoreit, Llion Jones, Aidan N. Gomez, Lukasz Kaiser, Illia Polosukhin
keyAssumptions: RNNs and CNNs are necessary for sequence transduction; Sequential computation limits parallelization
citation: Vaswani, A., Shazeer, N., Parmar, N., Uszkoreit, J., Jones, L., Gomez, A. N., ... & Polosukhin, I. (2017). Attention is all you need. Advances in neural information processing systems, 30.
notes: Foundational paper introducing the Transformer architecture. Key innovation: self-attention mechanism allows modeling dependencies without recurrence or convolution.

title: BERT: Pre-training of Deep Bidirectional Transformers for Language Understanding
authors: Jacob Devlin, Ming-Wei Chang, Kenton Lee, Kristina Toutanova
keyAssumptions: Unidirectional language models are sufficient for pre-training; Fine-tuning requires task-specific architectures
citation: Devlin, J., Chang, M. W., Lee, K., & Toutanova, K. (2019). BERT: Pre-training of deep bidirectional transformers for language understanding. In Proceedings of NAACL-HLT (pp. 4171-4186).
notes: Introduces bidirectional pre-training using masked language modeling. Shows that deep bidirectional representations significantly improve downstream task performance.

title: Robin: A multi-agent system for automating scientific discovery
authors: Ali Essam Ghareeb, Benjamin Chang, Ludovico Mitchener, Angela Yiu, Caralyn J. Szostkiewicz, Jon M. Laurent, Muhammed T. Razzak, Andrew D. White, Michaela M. Hinks, Samuel G. Rodriques
keyAssumptions: Individual research components must be automated separately; Full research integration is not feasible; Human oversight is necessary for meaningful insights
citation: Ghareeb, A. E., Chang, B., Mitchener, L., Yiu, A., Szostkiewicz, C. J., Laurent, J. M., ... & Rodriques, S. G. (2025). Robin: A multi-agent system for automating scientific discovery. arXiv preprint arXiv:2505.13400.
notes: First multi-agent system to achieve end-to-end scientific discovery with real-world validation. Identified ripasudil as novel dAMD therapeutic candidate through coordinated literature search, hypothesis generation, and data analysis agents.

title: The AI Scientist: Towards Fully Automated Open-Ended Scientific Discovery
authors: Chris Lu, Cong Lu, Robert Tjarko Lange, Jakob Foerster, Jeff Clune, David Ha
keyAssumptions: Scientific research requires human creativity and intuition; Automated systems can only assist with sub-tasks; End-to-end automation is not feasible
citation: Lu, C., Lu, C., Lange, R. T., Foerster, J., Clune, J., & Ha, D. (2024). The AI Scientist: Towards Fully Automated Open-Ended Scientific Discovery. arXiv preprint arXiv:2408.06292.
notes: First comprehensive framework for fully automated scientific workflow including idea generation, implementation, experimentation, analysis, and paper writing. Demonstrated generation of papers exceeding conference acceptance thresholds at ~$15 per paper.

title: The AI Scientist-v2: Workshop-Level Automated Scientific Discovery via Agentic Tree Search
authors: Yutaro Yamada, Robert Tjarko Lange, Cong Lu, Shengran Hu, Chris Lu, Jakob Foerster, Jeff Clune, David Ha
keyAssumptions: Automated research systems require extensive human-provided scaffolding; Domain-specific customization is necessary for effective operation
citation: Yamada, Y., Lange, R. T., Lu, C., Hu, S., Lu, C., Foerster, J., Clune, J., & Ha, D. (2025). The AI Scientist-v2: Workshop-Level Automated Scientific Discovery via Agentic Tree Search. arXiv preprint arXiv:2504.08066.
notes: Enhanced AI research system achieving first peer-reviewed AI-generated paper acceptance at ICLR workshop. Eliminated reliance on human templates through progressive agentic tree-search methodology.

title: Agentic AI for Scientific Discovery: A Survey of Progress, Challenges, and Future Directions
authors: Mourad Gridach, Jay Nanavati, Khaldoun Zine El Abidine, Lenon Mendes, Christina Mack
keyAssumptions: Agentic AI applications are domain-specific without common principles; No standardized evaluation frameworks exist; Systems operate in isolation
citation: Gridach, M., Nanavati, J., El Abidine, K. Z., Mendes, L., & Mack, C. (2025). Agentic AI for Scientific Discovery: A Survey of Progress, Challenges, and Future Directions. arXiv preprint arXiv:2503.08979.
notes: Comprehensive survey establishing taxonomies and evaluation standards for agentic AI in scientific discovery across chemistry, biology, and materials science. Identifies key challenges and future research directions.

title: BioDisco: Multi-agent hypothesis generation with dual-mode evidence, iterative feedback and temporal evaluation
authors: Yujing Ke, Kevin George, Kathan Pandya, Gerrit Großmann, David Blumenthal, Maximilian Sprang, Sebastian Vollmer, David Antony Selby
keyAssumptions: Hypothesis generation can rely primarily on literature synthesis; Structured reasoning processes are not necessary; Systematic uncertainty quantification is not required
citation: Ke, Y., George, K., Pandya, K., Großmann, G., Blumenthal, D., Sprang, M., Vollmer, S., & Selby, D. A. (2025). BioDisco: Multi-agent hypothesis generation with dual-mode evidence, iterative feedback and temporal evaluation. arXiv preprint arXiv:2508.01285.
notes: Multi-agent framework combining biomedical knowledge graphs with literature retrieval for evidence-grounded hypothesis generation. Demonstrates superior novelty through iterative feedback and temporal evaluation.
